description: Easy-Medium - Early Campaigns & Pyrrhus's Arrival in Italy

questions.question: What was Manius Curius Dentatus's role in the final conquest of southern Italy?
options: He was a diplomatic negotiator who secured peaceful incorporation of southern Italian peoples
He served as governor of Sicily and managed Roman colonial expansion in the Mediterranean
He returned from the Samnite Wars and immediately retired from military service entirely
He negotiated peace treaties with Greek cities and established trading relationships with Tarentum
He led military campaigns in southern Italy and commanded the conquest of Lucanian territories
questions.text_reference: Section 3: The Campaign in Southern Italy

questions.question: How did Roman military campaigns differ when fighting Lucanians and Bruttians compared to the Samnites?
options: Romans faced equally organized resistance and fought similar large-scale pitched battles
Romans focused on capturing strategic cities through siege warfare rather than large battles
Romans avoided military engagement and relied exclusively on diplomatic negotiations
Lucanians and Bruttians possessed superior tactical advantages in mountain terrain

questions.question: Why did Lucanian and Bruttian peoples offer limited resistance to Roman military expansion? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: They were already weakened from previous losses in the Samnite coalition wars
They lacked the military organization and unified leadership to mount effective coordinated resistance
They possessed superior military technology and weapons compared to Roman armies
They were individually conquered piecemeal rather than facing unified Roman opposition
They immediately negotiated peaceful surrender without attempting any military defense

questions.question: What qualities characterized Pyrrhus's invasion army from Epirus?
options: It consisted of elite mercenary soldiers recruited from throughout the Mediterranean region and beyond
It was a professional army trained in Hellenistic tactics with advanced Greek-style weaponry and equipment
It emphasized naval operations and featured specially designed ships for amphibious warfare tactics
It relied on local Italian recruits to supplement the core Epirote soldiers and strengthen overall forces

questions.question: What made war elephants so psychologically and militarily devastating to Roman soldiers at Heraclea?
options: Romans had studied Hellenistic elephant tactics extensively but lacked the cavalry units needed to counter them effectively
Elephants were completely unknown to Italian armies and caused panic that broke infantry formations, giving tactical advantage
Romans possessed weapons capable of harming elephants but soldiers refused to use them due to psychological fear
Elephants were slower than Roman forces but their heavy armor prevented cavalry from maneuvering around their flanks

questions.question: What was Pyrrhus's strategic situation and vision when he first arrived in Italy in 280 BCE?
options: He planned a brief campaign lasting only a few months before returning to Epirus immediately
He sought only to protect Tarentum from Roman expansion without pursuing broader territorial goals
He expected Italian peoples to rally massively to his cause and join his military forces
He aimed to establish trading relationships rather than pursuing military conquest or political dominance
He envisioned establishing himself as dominant power, defeating Rome, and creating lasting kingdom

questions.question: How did Pyrrhus underestimate Rome's capacity and determination in his initial strategic planning?
options: He believed military victory in battles would automatically translate into political dominance over Rome
He expected Roman negotiation and surrender after his first major military victory
He did not appreciate Rome's deep institutional capacity for waging prolonged warfare indefinitely
All of the above underestimations affected Pyrrhus's strategic planning and expectations

questions.question: In what year did Pyrrhus sail across the Adriatic Sea to Italy with his invasion force?
options: 290 BCE, immediately after the conclusion of Rome's Samnite Wars and conflicts
280 BCE, when Tarentum requested military assistance against Roman expansion southward
275 BCE, after Pyrrhus had consolidated power throughout Greece and the Balkans
265 BCE, during the early stages of the upcoming conflict between Rome and Carthage

questions.question: What circumstances allowed Pyrrhus to arrive in Italy at precisely the moment Tarentum needed military support?
options: Tarentum and Pyrrhus had previously negotiated an alliance and planned the invasion together
Pyrrhus was already conducting military campaigns nearby and could quickly redirect forces southward
Pyrrhus was seeking opportunities for conquest and glory, making the appeal ideally timed for him
Roman forces had specifically requested Pyrrhus's intervention to resolve their southern conflicts

questions.question: What advantages did Pyrrhus possess when he began his Italian campaign against Rome?
options: He had superior naval power and control of Mediterranean trade routes and commercial networks
He brought advanced Hellenistic military technology including trained war elephants Romans had never encountered
He had the support of all Italian peoples who viewed him as a liberator from Roman dominance
He possessed greater numbers of soldiers and unlimited resources to replace casualties indefinitely
